最近组装的列奥纳多·达·芬奇家谱，从 1331 年到现在跨越了 21 代，可​​以为 DNA 测试铺平道路，以确认埋在达·芬奇坟墓中的骨头是否真的是他的。然而，两位艺术史学家希望为这位文艺复兴时期艺术家的才华揭开遗传解释的希望，可能会被科学现实所摧毁。为了构建家谱，艺术史学家 Alessandro Vezzosi 和 Agnese Sabato 挖掘了过去 690 年的出生、死亡和财产记录。他们还采访了在世的亲属，以了解更多关于这位著名艺术家、科学家和发明家的现代大家庭的信息。最后，他们追踪了达芬奇的家族，从他出生于 1331 年的祖父到今天居住的 14 位亲戚。列奥纳多·达·芬奇本人没有孩子，他的现代亲戚都是他 22 个（！）同父异母的兄弟姐妹的后代。现在的家庭在这项新研究中发挥了重要作用。 Vezzosi 和 Sabato 写道：“他们中的许多人与他们的亲属合作收集和验证信息，并热情地帮助联系其他家庭成员并检索新的文件和图像。”那些多次成为伟大的侄女和侄子包括几名办公室工作人员（其中一个在 1960 年代担任海军炮手）、一名退休的室内装潢师、一名测量员和一名“对摩托车和音乐充满热情”的国家雇员。年龄最大的已经85岁了，最小的只有一岁。从一些有趣的历史角度来看，当黑死病到达意大利时，这位艺术家的祖父米歇尔·达·芬奇 (Michele da Vinci) 还只是个少年；他最近的 20 次侄女或侄子出生在 Covid-19 大流行期间。 Vezzosi 和 Sabato 对从达芬奇的父亲（一位名叫 Ser Piero da Vinci 的公证人）到今天几代人的男性血统特别感兴趣。这部分是因为在女性的生活——有时甚至是她们的整个存在——很少被记录在官方记录中的历史文献中，男性血统更容易被追踪。但这主要是因为 Y 染色体，这是人类基因组中唯一可以直接从父亲传给儿子的部分。除了随着时间的推移发生一些小的变化之外，达芬奇现代侄子的 Y 染色体应该与米歇尔、皮耶罗爵士和列奥纳多本人的 Y 染色体极为相似。这意味着，通过将现代亲属的 Y 染色体 DNA 与埋在达芬奇坟墓中的骨骼的古代 DNA 进行比较，有可能解开一个 158 年的谜团：谁被埋葬在圣教堂的达芬奇坟墓中。 -休伯特？列奥纳多·达·芬奇 (Leonardo da Vinci) 在法国度过了他生命的最后四年，在国王弗朗西斯一世 (King Francis I) 的宫廷中担任科学家和工程师。他于 1519 年去世，被埋葬在附近的圣佛罗伦萨教堂，距离他的家人大约 1,200 公里（750 英里）。 （据说，莱昂纳多与他的同父异母兄弟几乎没有接触；有几个比他小十多岁，历史文件表明在继承方面存在一些冲突。）
这位伟大的文艺复兴时期的学者在那里躺了 275 年左右，直到革命来到他的祖国。法国大革命期间，圣佛罗伦萨教堂大部分被拆毁；几年后，拿破仑·波拿巴完成了这项工作。在这个过程中，达芬奇的坟墓和他的骨头都消失了。工人们在 1863 年发现了一具骨架，埋在地下的还有一些刻有字母的石头碎片：“EO”、“AR”、“DUS”和“VINC”，发现者将其读为铭文的碎片，曾经“列奥纳达·达·芬奇说。”骷髅的牙齿看起来已经磨损得足以与达芬奇去世时的年龄相吻合，一块刻有弗朗西斯一世国王图像的银盾表明了正确的时期。今天，这具骨架位于附近圣休伯特教堂的一座坟墓中，但 DNA 测试可以帮助确认它是否真的是莱昂纳多。当然，这样的测试需要获得许可——可能来自教会、幸存的亲属、文化遗产官员，或这些的某种组合。目前尚不清楚是否有人会热衷于对被广泛认为是达芬奇骨架的破坏性采样。然而，有趣的是，骨架的所有权现在是一个可检验的假设，即使只是技术上。列奥纳多中世纪晚期和文艺复兴时期的大部分家庭成员都被埋葬在芬奇的圣十字教堂，这座小镇距离意大利佛罗伦萨约 20 英里，这个家族的名字也由此而来。后人将姓氏从“达芬奇”改为“芬奇”。但是，埋葬着艺术家的至少六名男性亲属的家族坟墓已经随着时间和教堂建筑的几次翻修而失传。这意味着莱昂纳多的祖父安东尼奥、他的叔叔弗朗西斯科和他同父异母的兄弟多梅尼科迪马特奥等人的尸体在技术上已经失踪，尽管他们几乎可以肯定仍然在现代教堂地板下的某个地方。 Vezzosi 和 Sabato 以及他们在国际达芬奇 DNA 项目中的同事对寻找这些坟墓很感兴趣，因为他们希望从达芬奇的几代男性家族中抽取 DNA 样本。他们声称，这将有助于确认近 700 年文件中记录的家谱与人与人之间的实际遗传关系相符。最近的一次探地雷达调查在教堂地板下寻找被遗忘的坟墓的痕迹。历史记载说，达芬奇古墓位于建筑中心附近，正门对面；通过将历史平面图与现代平面图进行比较，Vezzosi 和 Sabato 设法找到了曾经是中心的教堂区域，正门对面。在大约正确的位置，他们的雷达调查发现了两个异常现象——无线电波反射与周围土壤不同的地方。教会官员不太可能允许在祭坛前挖掘地板寻找达芬奇的亲属。挖掘多组遗骸以获取 DNA 样本可能需要大量资源并引发严重的道德问题。研究人员通常必须证明他们提出了非常引人注目的科学问题，才能获得开展此类项目的许可和资金，而对历史人物的家谱进行实地调查可能达不到标准。
许多 Vezzosi 和 Sabato 对达芬奇 DNA 的计划——如果它曾经被测序过——实际上并不具有科学意义。它们主要基于一些关于遗传、智力甚至种族的过时想法。对达芬奇的 DNA 进行测序，Vezzosi 和 Sabato 写道，“将提供有用的元素来科学探索他天才的根源，找到关于他的身体能力和他可能早熟的信息，关于他的左撇子和他的健康和可能的遗传性疾病，并解释某些特殊的感官知觉，比如他非凡的视觉质量和联觉。”一些特定的特征，例如左撇子和一些遗传性健康问题，可能至少部分地写入了达芬奇的基因中。其他的，比如联觉，可能有遗传基础，因为它往往在家庭中运行，但遗传学家还没有确定一个。但是没有已知的智力或创造力的遗传标记。 20 世纪早期危害极大的优生学运动是基于这样一种观点，即智力和道德是人们简单地从父母那里继承来的特征，这一观点今天仍然存在。但是科学讲述了一个非常不同的故事，环境影响与数百个基因的输入混合在一起，每个基因都有微小的影响。 “我们进一步认为莱昂纳多出生于两种不同单倍型的遗传相互作用，即来自两个不同种群的特征的假设具有重要意义和吸引力，”Vezzosi 和 Sabato 写道。一些历史学家认为达芬奇的母亲卡特琳娜可能是一名来自卡法或君士坦丁堡的被奴役的妇女，但韦佐西和萨巴托问道：“这会是列奥纳多天才的起源吗？”总而言之，研究列奥纳多的 DNA 以了解是什么让他感到兴奋的想法提供了一个很好的例子，说明为什么研究人员不应该盲目地离开自己的领域工作。多学科研究很重要，但当不同领域的专家一起工作时，效果最好。

A recently assembled Leonardo da Vinci family tree, spanning 21 generations from 1331 to the present, could pave the way for DNA testing that might confirm whether the bones interred in da Vinci’s grave are actually his. Two art historians’ hopes of uncovering a genetic explanation for the Renaissance artist’s brilliance, however, will probably be doomed by scientific reality.
  To construct the family tree, art historians Alessandro Vezzosi and Agnese Sabato dug through birth, death, and property records spanning the last 690 years. They also interviewed surviving relatives to learn more about the famous artist, scientist, and inventor’s modern extended family. In the end, they traced da Vinci’s family from his grandfather, born in 1331, to the 14 relatives living today. Leonardo da Vinci himself had no children, and his modern relatives all descend from his 22 (!) half-siblings.
 The present family played an essential role in the new study. “Many of them have collaborated, together with their relatives, to the collection and verification of information,” wrote Vezzosi and Sabato, “helping enthusiastically to contact other family members and retrieve new documents and images.” Those many-times-great nieces and nephews include several office workers (one of whom served as a naval gunner in the 1960s), a retired upholsterer, a surveyor, and a state employee who is “passionate about motorcycling and music.” The oldest is now 85 years old, and the youngest is just one year old.
 For some interesting historical perspective, the artist’s grandfather, Michele da Vinci, would have been a teenager when the Black Death arrived in Italy; his latest 20-times-great niece or nephew was born during the Covid-19 pandemic.
  Vezzosi and Sabato were especially interested in the male line of descent from da Vinci’s father, a notary named Ser Piero da Vinci, to today’s generations. That’s partly because the male line is easier to trace in historical documents from a time where women’s lives—and sometimes their whole existence—seldom got written down in official records. But it’s mostly because of the Y chromosome, the only part of the human genome that gets passed down directly from father to son. Aside from some small changes that happen over time, the Y-chromosomes of da Vinci’s modern nephews should be extremely similar to those of Michele, Ser Piero, and Leonardo himself.
 That means that by comparing the Y chromosome DNA of modern relatives to ancient DNA from the skeleton buried in da Vinci’s grave, it may be possible to solve a 158-year-old mystery: who is buried in da Vinci’s grave in the Chapel of Saint-Hubert?
    Leonardo da Vinci spent the last four years of his life in France, working as a scientist and engineer in the court of King Francis I. He lived and worked in the town of Amboise, a stone’s throw from the king’s summer palace, and when he died in 1519, he was buried in the nearby church of St. Florentine, about 1,200 km (750 miles) from the rest of his family. (By all accounts, Leonardo had little contact with his half-brothers; several were more than a decade younger, and historical documents suggest some conflicts over inheritance.)
 And there the great Renaissance scholar lay for the next 275 years or so, until revolution came to his adopted country. During the French Revolution, the church of St. Florentine was mostly demolished; Napoleon Bonaparte finished the job a few years later. In the process, da Vinci’s tomb, and his bones, disappeared.
 Workers at the site found a skeleton in 1863, buried along with some fragments of stone carved with letters: “EO,” “AR,” “DUS,” and “VINC,” which the finders read as broken pieces of an inscription that once said “Leonardus da Vinci.” The skeleton’s teeth looked worn enough to fit da Vinci’s age when he died, and a silver shield etched with an image of King Francis I suggested the right time period. Today, the skeleton resides in a tomb at the nearby Chapel of Saint-Hubert, but DNA testing could help confirm whether it’s really Leonardo.
 Of course, such testing would require permission—possibly from the church, from surviving relatives, from cultural heritage officials, or some combination of those. It’s unclear whether anyone would be keen on destructive sampling from what is widely believed to be the skeleton of Leonardo da Vinci. However, it’s interesting that ownership of the skeleton is a testable hypothesis now, even if only technically.
  Most of Leonardo’s late medieval and Renaissance-era family members were buried in the church of Santa Croce in Vinci, a town about 20 miles from Florence, Italy, from which the family gets its name. Later generations changed the family name from "da Vinci" to just "Vinci." But the family tomb, in which at least six of the artist’s male relatives are buried, has been lost to time and several renovations of the church building. That means the bodies of Leonardo’s grandfather Antonio, his uncle Francesco, and his half-brother Domenico di Matteo, among others, are technically missing, although they're almost certainly still somewhere under the modern church floor.
 Vezzosi and Sabato and their colleagues at the International Leonardo da Vinci DNA Project are interested in finding those graves because they hope to sample DNA from several generations of da Vinci’s male family line. That, they claim, would help confirm that the family tree recorded in nearly 700 years of documents matches the actual genetic relationships between people.
    A recent ground-penetrating radar survey looked for traces of forgotten tombs under the church floor. Historical records say the old da Vinci tomb lay near the center of the building, opposite its main door; by comparing historical floor plans to modern ones, Vezzosi and Sabato managed to find the area of the church that would once have been the center, opposite the main door. And in about the right spot, their radar survey detected two anomalies—places where the radio waves reflect differently than in the surrounding soil.
 It’s unlikely that church officials would grant permission to dig up the floor in front of the altar to look for Leonardo da Vinci’s relatives. Exhuming several sets of remains to get DNA samples would likely require significant resources and raise serious ethical concerns. Researchers typically have to show that they’re asking very compelling scientific questions in order to get permission and funding to undertake that kind of project, and ground-truthing a historical figure’s family tree probably falls short of the standard.
  Many of Vezzosi and Sabato's plans for da Vinci’s DNA—if it’s ever sequenced—don’t actually make scientific sense. They’re largely based on some outdated ideas about heredity, intelligence, and even race.
 Sequencing Leonardo da Vinci's DNA, Vezzosi and Sabato wrote, “will make available useful elements to scientifically explore the roots of his genius, to find information on his physical prowess and on his possibly precocious aging, on his being left-handed and his health and possible hereditary sicknesses, and to explain certain peculiar sensory perceptions, like his extraordinary visual quality and synesthesia.”
 A few specific traits, like left-handedness and some hereditary health problems, might be at least partially written in da Vinci’s genes. Others, like synesthesia, may have a genetic basis since it tends to run in families, but geneticists haven’t yet pinpointed one. But there’s no known genetic marker for intelligence or creativity. The deeply harmful eugenics movement of the early 20 th century was based on the idea that intelligence and morality were traits that people simply inherited from their parents, an idea that persists today.  But science tells a very different story, with environmental influences mixing with the input of hundreds of genes, each having a tiny effect.
 “We further deem significant and fascinating the hypothesis that Leonardo was born from a genetic interaction of two different haplotypes, that is, from the characteristics of two different populations,” Vezzosi and Sabato wrote. Some historians have suggested that da Vinci’s mother Caterina may have been an enslaved woman from Caffa or Constantinople, but Vezzosi and Sabato speculate by asking, “Could this be the origin of Leonardo’s genius?”
  All in all, the idea of studying Leonardo’s DNA to learn what made him tick offers a great example of why researchers shouldn’t just blindly charge off to work outside their own fields. Multidisciplinary research is important, but it works best when experts in different fields work together.

随着高度传播的 delta 变体的迅速增加和国家疫苗接种工作的基本停滞，COVID-19 大流行继续在美国未接种疫苗的人群中肆虐——情况看起来很严峻。 COVID-19 病例在所有 50 个州和哥伦比亚特区都在上升。目前，每 10 万人每日新增病例平均数最高的州是阿肯色州、密苏里州、佛罗里达州、路易斯安那州和内华达州，它们的疫苗接种率均低于平均水平。在全国范围内，过去两周平均每日病例增加了 140%。住院人数和死亡人数的增幅落后于数周，也分别增长了 34% 和 33%。相对于大流行的其余部分，全国的病例数、住院人数和死亡人数较低——它们与 2020 年 4 月的数字相当或低于。但在某些地方未接种疫苗的病例率与大流行的高度。疫苗接种覆盖率低的地区正在出现激增。密苏里州——只有 40% 的人口完全接种了疫苗——每天的新病例率与去年 10 月冬季高峰期的情况一样高。该州的一些热点正在创造记录。例如，在西南部的塔尼县，现在每天新增病例的 7 天平均值高于以往任何时候，平均每天新增病例 55 例。此前的最高平均水平是每天 45 例新病例，该县在 11 月 22 日和 12 月 10 日再次出现。在阿肯色州的边境，巴克斯特县上周创下了每日新病例的最高平均记录，即 42每天的案例。这超过了 1 月初创下的 32 人之前的记录。巴克斯特县只有 33% 的人口接种了全面疫苗。这些病例激增正在转化为住院人数的增加。在百特，过去两周住院人数增加了 340%。在密苏里州西南部，医院已经不堪重负，重症监护室已满负荷运转，呼吸机不足，医院报告护士短缺。上周，密苏里州斯普林菲尔德-格林县卫生局要求州政府拨款建立一家野战医院，以帮助应对 COVID-19 重症患者激增的情况。在这些地方和全国其他地方，绝大多数因 COVID-19 住院的人都未接种疫苗。在上周五的白宫新闻发布会上，疾病控制与预防中心主任罗谢尔·瓦伦斯基重申，全国进入医院的 COVID-19 患者中有 97% 以上未接种疫苗。随着低疫苗接种率，delta冠状病毒变种的传播是惨淡激增的背后。据估计，Delta 的传染性是最初的大流行冠状病毒株的两倍多。自 2020 年 12 月在印度首次发现以来，它已成为世界上最主要的变种。自从 3 月份在美国首次发现它以来，它已成为这里的主要菌株，迅速超过 alpha (B.1.1.7)。帮助超传播变种传播的事实是，它到达时恰逢美国许多人开始放松警惕，放松口罩的使用和保持身体距离。
完全接种疫苗的人在很大程度上免受三角洲的影响；当前的疫苗对于从 delta 和其他令人关注的变体中开发出 COVID-19 仍然非常有效。尽管一小部分人会出现所谓的“突破性感染”，但这些感染大多是无症状或轻微的。但是未接种疫苗的人是完全脆弱的。此外，那些只接种了一剂两剂疫苗或仅从 COVID-19 中康复的人并不比完全未接种疫苗的人好多少。在本月早些时候发表在《自然》杂志上的一项研究中，研究人员测试了在大流行早期（即 delta 出现之前）从 COVID-19 中康复的人的免疫反应。具体来说，研究人员研究了参与者的中和抗体——最有效的抗体类型，被认为对预防大流行性冠状病毒至关重要。研究人员观察从早期 COVID-19 病例中康复的人，发现他们的中和抗体在抵抗 delta 变体方面的效果比在抵抗早期版本的病毒方面低四到六倍。同样，仅接受一剂 mRNA 疫苗的人几乎没有任何可检测到的对 delta 起作用的中和抗体。但是，当康复者接种一剂疫苗或部分接种疫苗的人接种第二剂时，中和抗体会猛增，这两个群体都被认为受到高度保护。这一发现促使健康专家更加强烈地呼吁接种疫苗，如果及时接种，这显然对 delta 有效。 Delta 正在迅速蔓延，可能需要长达六周的时间才能完全接种疫苗并受到保护。对于那些仍未接种疫苗的人来说，尽快接种疫苗以避免感染和传播 delta 至关重要。但根据哥伦比亚广播公司新闻的新民意调查数据，新一波疫苗接种似乎不太可能。在未接种疫苗和部分接种疫苗的人群中，只有 48% 的人表示他们担心 delta。在完全接种疫苗的人群中，72% 的人表示担心这种变异。尽管目前的 COVID-19 疫苗已被证明非常有效和安全，但 53% 未接种或部分接种疫苗的人在民意调查中表示，他们担心副作用。 50% 的受访者认为对政府缺乏信任是不接种疫苗的原因。 45% 的人说他们不相信科学。所有这些百分比都高于早先的民意调查，这表明这些反疫苗情绪在未接种疫苗的人群中越来越强烈。一些可能更有说服力的未接种疫苗的人表示，他们正在等待疫苗获得食品和药物管理局的全面批准（目前，他们在紧急使用授权下获得了 FDA 的授权）。周五，辉瑞和 BioNTech 表示，FDA 已授予他们 mRNA 疫苗的优先审评资格，但他们预计要到 2022 年 1 月才能做出全面批准的决定。
目前，疫苗供应商每天仅接种约 520,000 支 COVID-19 疫苗，低于 4 月份每天 460 万支的记录。有超过 1.61 亿人接种了疫苗，但只有 48.6% 的美国人口完全接种了疫苗。

With the rapid rise of the highly transmissible delta variant and national vaccination efforts largely stalled, the COVID-19 pandemic continues to rage among the unvaccinated in the US—and things are looking grim.
 Cases of COVID-19 are rising in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Right now, the states with the highest averages for daily new cases per 100,000 people are Arkansas, Missouri, Florida, Louisiana, and Nevada, which all have below-average vaccination rates. Nationwide, average daily cases are up 140 percent over the past two weeks. Hospitalizations and deaths, which lag behind increases in cases by weeks, are also up 34 percent and 33 percent, respectively.
 Relative to the rest of the pandemic, the nationwide numbers of cases, hospitalizations, and deaths are low—they're matching or are below numbers seen back in April of 2020. But  rates of cases among the unvaccinated in some places rival those seen at the heights of the pandemic. And areas with low vaccination coverage are seeing surges.
 Missouri—with just 40 percent of its population fully vaccinated—is seeing daily new case rates as high as those seen last October, at the foot of the winter peak. And some hot spots in the state are setting records. In the southwestern county of Taney, for instance, the seven-day average for daily new cases is higher now than at any point previously, with an average of 55 new cases per day. The previous highest average was 45 new cases per day, which the county hit on November 22 and again on December 10. Across the border in Arkansas, Baxter county set a record last week for its highest average of daily new cases, which was 42 new cases per day. That surpassed its previous record of 32, set in early January. Only 33 percent of Baxter county's population is fully vaccinated.
    These case surges are translating to increases in hospitalizations. In Baxter, hospitalizations are up 340 percent over the last two weeks. In southwestern Missouri,  hospitals have become overwhelmed, with intensive care units hitting capacity, ventilators running low, and hospitals reporting nursing shortages. Last week, Missouri's Springfield-Greene County Health Department  requested state funding to set up a field hospital to help handle the surge in patients with severe COVID-19 cases.
  In these places and elsewhere across the country, the vast majority of those hospitalized with COVID-19 are unvaccinated.  In a White House press briefing last Friday, Rochelle Walensky, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, reiterated that more than 97 percent of COVID-19 patients entering hospitals nationwide are unvaccinated.
 Along with the low vaccination rates, the spread of the delta coronavirus variant is behind the bleak surges. Delta is estimated to be more than twice as infectious as the original pandemic coronavirus strain. Since it was first detected in India in December 2020, it has become the most dominant variant in the world. And since it was first detected in the US in March, it has become  the dominant strain here, quickly overtaking alpha (B.1.1.7). Helping the hyper-transmissible variant spread is the fact that it arrived just as many people in the US began letting their guard down, easing mask use and physical distancing.
 Fully vaccinated people are largely protected from delta; the current vaccines are still highly effective against developing COVID-19 from delta and other variants of concern. Though a small proportion of people can develop so-called "breakthrough infections," those infections will mostly be asymptomatic or mild. But unvaccinated people are completely vulnerable. Moreover, those who have received only one dose of a two-dose vaccine or have only recovered from COVID-19 are not much better off than those who are completely unvaccinated.
 In  a study published in Nature earlier this month, researchers tested the immune responses of people who had recovered from COVID-19 early on in the pandemic, before delta arose. Specifically, the researchers looked at the participants' neutralizing antibodies—the most potent type of antibody that is thought to be critical for protection against the pandemic coronavirus. Looking at people who had recovered from early cases of COVID-19, researchers found their neutralizing antibodies were four- to six-fold less effective at fighting off the delta variant than they were at fighting off earlier versions of the virus. Likewise, people who had only received one dose of an mRNA vaccine barely had any detectable neutralizing antibodies that worked against delta.
    But when recovered people received one vaccine dose or when partially vaccinated people received their second dose, neutralizing antibodies shot up, and both groups were considered highly protected.
  The finding spurred health experts to intensify their calls for vaccination, which is clearly effective against delta—if it's done in time. Delta is spreading quickly, and it can take up to six weeks to become fully vaccinated and protected. It is critical for those who remain unvaccinated to get their shots as quickly as possible to avoid catching and spreading delta.
 But according to  new polling data from CBS News, a new wave of vaccinations seems unlikely. Among unvaccinated and partly vaccinated people, only 48 percent said they are concerned about delta. Among fully vaccinated people, 72 percent reported being concerned about the variant.
 Despite the fact that the current COVID-19 vaccines have proven highly effective and safe, 53 percent of those who are unvaccinated or partly vaccinated said in the poll that they are concerned about side effects. Fifty percent of the group cited a lack of trust in the government as a reason not to get vaccinated. And 45 percent said they don't trust the science. All of these percentages are higher than they have been in earlier polls, indicating that these anti-vaccine sentiments are hardening among the unvaccinated.
 Some unvaccinated people who may be more persuadable have said they are  waiting for the vaccines to receive full approval from the Food and Drug Administration (currently, they are authorized by the FDA under an emergency use authorization). On Friday, Pfizer and BioNTech said that the FDA had granted them  a Priority Review designation for their mRNA vaccine, but they didn't expect a decision on full approval until January 2022.
 Currently, vaccine providers are administering only around 520,000 COVID-19 vaccines per day, down from a record of 4.6 million in a day in April. With over 161 million people vaccinated, only  48.6 percent of the US population is fully vaccinated.
